title: 100-gon!
100 got mad!
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{cases} xyzw & = 1 \\ x^{100} + 100y & = 100z + w^{100} \\ 100x + y^{100} & = z^{100} + 100w \end{cases} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" (x,y,z,w) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" be positive real numbers that satisfy the system of equations above. Find the minimum possible value of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" x + y + z + w"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For more problems on finding maximum and minimum, click "},{"type":"text","text":"here","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"heading","attrs":[{"level":6}],"content":[{"type":"text","text":"Try another problem on my set! Warming Up and More Practice"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"As "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x, y, z, w"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are positive real numbers, we have that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac { x+y+z+w }{ 4 } \ge \sqrt [ 4 ]{ xyzw } =1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Thus "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"min(x + y + z + w) = 4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"By the way, the second and third equation is somewhat useless."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            That is why I said that it's pretty much useless when the second and third equation also holds true when x = y = z = w = 1.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"

                                            Thanks btw. I will edit the solution later.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

And now think over this and tell me the minimum value of x+y+z+w

title: 100 head 100 Dollar
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"You are having $100 .You should buy X number of elephants ,Y number of donkeys and Z
number of horses.But there is a condition that you should buy 100 animals with $100."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"prices are;1 elephant is $5,1 donkey is $2^-1 and 1 horse  is $2^-2."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Find the smallest value of XYZ"}]}]}

title: 100 Hours Later
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If it is now 5:00 AM, then what time will it be in 100 hours?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                    "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Relevant wiki: Modular Arithmetic - Addition","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 100 = 24 \times 4 + 4 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", so 100 hours would be 4 days and 4 hours later."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4 hours after 5:00 AM would be 9:00 AM."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            I did the same thing. I happen to have memorized the fact that 96 hours represents four days, so I just added four more hours and got 9:00AM. Taking advantage of the fact that the time cycled back to 5:00AM every 24 hours and that no real change could take place until the end when there weren't enough hours left for it to cycle back to the starting position. It's like when you work with a circle and you're given an angle that's over 360 degrees, only much easier because you're dealing with a more familiar unit and smaller numbers.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Did the same thing.Thanks for the solution.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We know that:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 100 \equiv 4 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \text{mod} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 24 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore, the times 100 hours later is: "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 5:00+4:00=\boxed{9:00 AM } "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            That is actually what I did to figure it out.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100 = 24×4 +4. So  4 Days and 4 Hours later.
4 hours after 5:00 AM is 9:00 AM"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"24/100=4, +4hours
5:00am+4=9:00am"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100=24×4+4,
100th hour from now would be four days and four hour later from now.
So after 100th hour it would be 5AM+four hour=9AM"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100hrs/24hrs(1day)=4days+4hrs
Which results to 5am on 4th day+4hrs=9am  on 4th day or 9am after 100 hours."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100((24+24+24+24)+4)
             ----------->5AM+4Hours=9AM"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We know that the day is 24 hours, so 
100 hours = 96 hours with 4 days + 4"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So the time will be 5:00 + 4:00  = 9:00 AM"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Another way to look at it:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If it's 5am that means there are 19 hrs remaining to complete the 24hrs cycle. So that leaves you adding 19 + (24*3) = 91 thus knowing it is 9 am"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We know that 24 hours = 1 day. So after 24 hours the time is always same
=>100 %24 =  4 hours (Extra Left).
Add 4 to 5. We get 9 A.M."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100 hours / 24 = [whatever the number] with a remainder of 4"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So 5:00 + 4:00 = 9:00"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            100 hours leading to 48 days? Are you sure?

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            i think you have made a mistake that 100 hours equal 48 days and 4 hours. It's just  4 days and 4 hours

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Remainder of 100/24 is 4. "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
So 5AM+4 hours is 9AM"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 100 jumps
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/O8EwdviuUe-stepping-stones.jpg?width=1200"}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"An infinite line of stepping stones stretches out into an infinitely large lake."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A frog starts on the second stone."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Every second he takes a jump to a neighboring stone.  He has a probability, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"p"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", of jumping one stone further away from the shore and a probability, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1-p"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", of jumping one stone closer to the shore."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If the "},{"type":"text","text":"expected value","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":" for the number of jumps he will take before reaching the first stone is exactly 100, then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"p"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" can be expressed as "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \dfrac ab"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are coprime positive integers, find "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a+b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"heading","attrs":[{"level":6}],"content":[{"type":"text","text":"Other Expected Value quizzes."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Image credit:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":"  smwmarketingny.com"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"E_n ="}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" Expected number of jumps to reach the first stone from the "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"th stone."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"From the second stone he has "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1-p"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" probability of jumping backward (to the first stone) and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"p"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" probability of jumping forward (to the third stone).  So,"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"E_2 = 1 + (1-p)*E_1 + p * E_3"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"E_1 = 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", this becomes,"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"E_2 = 1 + p * E_3"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"However, by symmetry, if he gets to the third stone, his expectation value has doubled from when he was on the second stone, since the the expected number of jumps to go from "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the same as the expected number of jumps to go from "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"E_3 = 2*E_2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".  "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore,  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"E_2 = 1 + p*(2E_2)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"And, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"E_2 = 100"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Solving for p, then,"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"p = 99/200"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"99+200 = \boxed{299}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 100 km Tunnel
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/YEfHboCvmW-330px-big-hill-tunnel-bendigo-line.jpg?width=1200"}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"There is a train which is 100 km in length and is going at 100km/h. The train is about to go through a tunnel which is exactly 100 km in length. "},{"type":"text","text":"How long is it, until the train completely passes through and comes out of the tunnel?","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Image credit "},{"type":"text","text":"Wikipedia","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The tunnel length is 100km
The length of the train is also 100km. "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
Speed of the train is 100km/h. 
(it means the train will travel 100kms in 1 hour)."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore, when the engine passes the tunnel, its 1 hour, but the train is itself also another 100 km long
So, in this case the total time taken by the complete train to leave the tunnel = (length of tunnel + length of the train ).
                                                                                                                           = (100 + 100) km.
                                                                                                                speed =  100 km/h.
                                                                                                          time taken = (200/100) = 2h."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"From, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\mbox{speed}=\dfrac{\mbox{distance}}{\mbox{time}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", we have"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100=\dfrac{100}{\mbox{time}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\mbox{time}=1~hour"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"However the train is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100~km"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", so the total time is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1+1="}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{2~hours}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 100 marbles
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Magi has 100 marbles - red, blue and colorful. The colorful and red marbles are 74 and blue and red marbles are 46. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"\n\n"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"How many colorful marbles does Magi have?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The answer is 54."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"You can find the answer quickly if you want or to find each tip of marbles."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"bulletList","content":[{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Here is the quickest way:"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100 (all the marbles) - 46 (blue and red)= 54 (the colorful marbles) "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Answer 54 colorful marbles."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"bulletList","content":[{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"text","text":"And here is the way to find each tip: "}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100 (all the marbles) - 74 (the colorful and red marbles) = 26 (blue marbles)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"46 (blue and red marbles) - 26 (blue marbles) = 20 (red marbles)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100 (all the marbles) - ( 20+26(red and blue marbles)) = 54 (colorful marbles)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Answer 54 colorful marbles."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 100 m Sprint
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/kIm2cPaEYG-03_usain-bolt.jpg?width=1200"}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The following 8 sprinters will participate in a fictitious 100 m sprint: "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
Usain Bolt: Jamaica, "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
Yohan Blake:Jamaica, "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
Asafa Powell :Jamaica, "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
Tyson Gray :USA, "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
Richard Thompson :Trinidad and Tobago, "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
Donovan Bailey: Canada, "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
Olusoji Fasuba: Nigeria, and "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
Frankie Fredericks: Namibia"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If the TWO rules below need to be followed, how many different lane assignments are possible?"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"orderedList","content":[{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"text","text":"NO two sprinters from the same country can be in adjacent lanes."}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The outside lanes ( 1 and 8) can't be occupied by sprinters from the same country."}]}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"There are 2 cases we have to consider: one of the outside lane is occupied by a Jamaica sprinter and all Jamaica sprinters are on the inside lanes."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Case 1: one of the outside lane is occupied by a Jamaica sprinter","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"From the 3 Jamaica sprinters, we choose 1 to stand on a outside lane (Let's say, lane 1) (the number of cases for lane 8 is the same, so just times 2 finally)."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Then the other 2 Jamaica sprinters can only stand on lane 3-7 due to the rules, and they cannot stand adjacent to each others, which yield 6 possible arrangements for them (remember, each arrangement yields "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2!"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" combinations!) "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(3, 5), (3, 6), (3, 7), (4, 6), (4, 7), (5, 7)"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For the rest of 5 sprinter, just arrange them randomly on the 5 remaining lanes.  Therefore there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5!"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for these 5 sprinter."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So the possible assignments in this case is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3 \times 2 \times 6 \times 2! \times 5! = 8640"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Case 2: all Jamaica sprinters are on the inside lanes","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"All Jamaica sprinters can only stand on lane 2-7 without "adjacenting" to each other, which only yields 4 possible arrangements for them (remember, each arrangement yields "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3!"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" combinations!) "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(2, 4, 6), (2, 4, 7), (2, 5, 7), (3, 5, 7)"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Again, the remaining 5 sprinters yield "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5!"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" combinations on the 5 remaining lanes."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So the possible assignments in this case is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4 \times 3! \times 5! = 2880"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"At last, add up all possible assignments, we have "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"8640+2880=\boxed{11520}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 100% Natural!
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/solvable/f3f0dc3139.0e76292794.nEnsaR.jpg?width=250"}},{"type":"text","text":"\nAll the natural numbers from 1 to 100 are arranged in a circle such that each number is either larger than both of its neighbours, or smaller than both of its neighbours. A pair of neighbouring numbers is "},{"type":"text","text":"good","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":" if the above-described property holds. What is the minimum number of pairs that can be "},{"type":"text","text":"good","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":"?"}]}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            I thought it should be 100 pairs since they are placed in a circle, such as:1-2,2-3,3-4,4-5,etc. Besides, the problem asks for the minimum, not the maximum. 
I'm not claiming I'm right: my answer is stated to be wrong, but I couldn't see why.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

title: 100% Natural

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned} f(x) & = \ln (1+x) - \ln (1-x) = \ln \left(\frac {1+x}{1-x} \right) 
\\ \implies f \left(\frac {2x}{1+x^2} \right) & = \ln \left(\frac {1+\frac {2x}{1+x^2}}{1-\frac {2x}{1+x^2}} \right)
\\ & = \ln \left(\frac {x^2 + 2x + 1}{x^2-2x+1} \right)
\\ & = \ln \left(\frac {1+x}{1-x} \right)^2
\\ & = 2 \ln \left(\frac {1+x}{1-x} \right)
\\ & = 2 f(x) \end{aligned} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k = \boxed 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":"@Ethan Mandelez"}],"attrs":[{"profile":"https://brilliant.org/profile/ethan-9otshx/"}]},{"type":"text","text":", you should learn up how to use LaTex for your solutions.  Note that it should be \ln x "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\ln x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (the ln is not italic but x is italic and there is a space between ln and x) and not ln x "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"ln x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (all are italic and no space in between).  Can used display fraction \dfrac \pi 2 "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\dfrac \pi 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" instead of just \frac 12 "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac 12"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".  Use \left(\dfrac mn \right) "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\left(\dfrac mn \right)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", then the brackets size is automatically adjusted.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            thanks for the tip! I'll do it next time 👍

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}
